{{EngvarB|date=February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} [[File:EBC selfie 1922.jpg|200px|thumb|EBC selfie 1922]] [[File:ABCHorsesclean.jpg|350px|thumb|Robert Henry Theatrical Company, 1899 New Zealand. Ernest is the small boy atop the rear of the carriage]] '''Ernest Gustav Brandon-Cremer''' (15 February 1895 – 1 March 1957) was a New Zealand/Australian moviemaker, newsman, explorer and adventurer. He was a key figure in Australian aviation history, and was especially known for his documentation of [[Lasseter's Reef|Lasseter's Gold Reef]] as well as his photography of the [[Solar eclipse of 21 September 1922]] at [[Wallal]], Australia.
== Early life == In Dunedin, New Zealand, Brandon-Cremer was born to [[Albert Wilhelm Anton Brandon-Cremer]] and Annie Beaton in a theatrical family,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/67803392|title=Amusements|work=Advocate|location=Burnie, Tasmania|date=14 March 1929|page=2|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/27094912|title=Still Acts at 80 Years of Age|work=The Mercury|location=Hobart, Tasmania|date=19 June 1952|page=6|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> his parents traversing New Zealand and Australia by horse and carriage over several decades in the early days of vaudeville in Australasia.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/67803392|title=Amusements|date=14 March 1929|work=Advocate|location=Burnie, Tasmania|page=2|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/27094912|title=Still Acts at 80 Years of Age|date=19 June 1952|work=The Mercury|location=Hobart, Tasmania|page=6|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
His childhood was marked by a never present father and an alcoholic mother, a marriage soon to be dissolved with the children abandoned to the State.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/167207632|title=Theatrical Divorce Case|work=Sydney Sportsman|location=Surry Hills, New South Wales|date=31 May 1905|page=2|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Brandon-Cremer ran away from home at 11 and had to fend for himself. Brandon-Cremer claims that he was taken in by a travelling American minister and he ended up spending the next 6 years in Hollywood.
In 1913, he was tried in [[Adelaide]] for breaking and entering, including theft, and sentenced to 18 months in prison.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/210006424|title=A Housebreaker Caught|work=The Express and Telegraph|location=Adelaide, South Australia|date=6 May 1913|page=1|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> A later court visit for vagrancy in June 1915<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/153603251|title=Camberwell Police Court|work=Camberwell and Hawthorn Adviser|location=Victoria|date=10 July 1915|page=7|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> showed he was now in Melbourne. In both instances he listed his profession as [[cinematographer]], a craft he repeatedly contended to have picked up on his travels to Hollywood; in one statement, he indicated that he worked for the  [[Vitagraph Company of America|Vitagraph Company of America,]] beginning in 1910.
Newspaper notices and advertisements show that Brandon-Cremer worked as a cinematographer with A. C. Tinsdale starting in 1915,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/154811358|title=Local Moving Pictures|work=The Ballarat Star|location=Victoria|date=3 April 1917|page=2|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> a relationship that would last many years, and would benefit him greatly.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/83117474|title=Dangerous Neglect|work=the Daily News|location=Perth, West Australia|date=5 December 1921|page=4|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> In May 1917 Brandon-Cremer became second wireless operator aboard the Steamship 'Boonah' as he headed for the UK.<ref name="Stranded in London">{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/83116722|title=Stranded in London|work=The Daily News|location=Perth, Western Australia|date=1 December 1921|page=7|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> In August 1917 he joined the [[Royal Garrison Artillery|British Garrison Artillery]] (BGA), part of the UK [[Royal Horse Artillery]] as a gunner (serial no. 198613). It seems he never saw active service over his 18 months with the BGA, but did qualify for several medals.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/D2001630|title=Medal Card of Ernest Brandon Cremer as Ernest B Cremer|work=UK National Archives|location=London|via=UK National Archives}}</ref> In press interviews later in life, Brandon-Cremer said he was "associated" with the R.A.F. and consequently saw service with the [[Polar Bear Expedition|British North Russian Relief Force]] in Russia during the [[Allied intervention in the Russian Civil War]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/41208395|title=Making Movies|date=23 August 1933|work=Cairns Post|location=Queensland|page=6|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and took part in the evacuation of [[Arkhangelsk|Archangel]] in northern Russia) in late 1919<ref name="Daring Death in Keystone Army">{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/234279275|title=Daring Death in Keystone Army|date=1 July 1922|work=Smith's Weekly|location=Sydney, New South Wales|page=13|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> He has stated he earned the [[Distinguished Flying Cross (United Kingdom)|Distinguished Flying Cross]], (not verified){{Citation needed|date=October 2017|reason=Reliable source needed for the whole sentence}} and displayed this medal (evidence of his flying ability can be found in the short travelogue "In and Around MacKay" (1933),<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/172946282|title=Theatre Royal|date=7 June 1933|work=Daily Mercury|location=Mackay, Queensland|page=13|type=Advertisement|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> where he is seen in the cockpit flying above MacKay)
Upon his BGA discharge in February 1919, Brandon-Cremer started a 15-month stint with the London YMCA as a cinematographer.<ref name="Stranded in London" /> Two months later, on 19 April, he married Minnie Henrietta Warren. Minnie, age 22, from London. He listed his occupation as Film Operator. It seems Minnie died the following year .
In June 1920 Brandon-Cremer went to work in South Africa for a year making short films for the South African Film Trust.<ref name="Stranded in London" /> On 11 July 1921 he returned to the UK aboard the RMS 'Kinfauns' from South Africa.{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}}
== The Spanish Foreign Legion, 1921 == In August 1921, Brandon-Cremer travelled to Spain to join the [[Spanish Legion]] fighting the Moors (Rif) in North Africa, and participated in 11 battles. He was repatriated to the UK in November, giving interviews to the British press, representing himself as the only Australian (New Zealander) to join the Spanish Legion. He later claimed to have been under the command of then Capt. [[Francisco Franco]] (subsequent dictator of Spain).<ref name="Daring Death in Keystone Army" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/41762761|title=General Franco|work=Cairns Post|location=Queensland|date=15 September 1936|page=11|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
His accounts of the ill treatment of British recruits to the Spanish Legion were widely reported in American, British and Australian newspapers. Upon reading such reports, his former business partner, A. C. Tinsdale started a campaign to return Brandon-Cremer to Australia.<ref name="Stranded in London" /> It seems that this was accomplished as Brandon-Cremer returned to Albany, Western Australia aboard the MS [[MS Akaroa (1914)|Euripides]] on 9 March 1922.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://recordsearch.naa.gov.au/SearchNRetrieve/Interface/ListingReports/PassengerListing.aspx|title=Passenger List, Ernest returns to Australia|via=National Archives of Australia}}</ref>
== The Eclipse at Wallal, Western Australia, 1922 == [[Wallal]], Western Australia was the chosen location for a visiting US [[Lick Observatory]] party of Astronomers, led by [[William Wallace Campbell|W. W. Campbell]], to view the upcoming [[Solar eclipse of 21 September 1922]]. The purpose of the expedition to view stellar transits of the Sun's disk during the eclipse to measure and verify [[Albert Einstein]]'s [[Theory of relativity]]. Wallal was preferred for its isolation from man-made light sources, its propensity for clear skies and its location to gain the longest eclipse duration.
Brandon-Cremer, along with his business partner C. A. Sharpe were hired to document the expedition in both still photography and moving picture film.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/210612470|title=The Solar Eclipse|work=The Express and Telegraph|location=Adelaide, South Australia|date=14 August 1922|page=2|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Hundreds of images from the team are kept at the archives of the [[University of California, Santa Cruz]] (donated by the Lick Observatory), and a second source of photos are kept at the Western Australia archives in [[Perth Australia|Perth]]. A film made by Brandon-Cremer entitled ''Astronomers and Aborigines'' was distributed globally<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/218224529|title=Eclipse Film|work=Daily Mail|location=Brisbane, Queensland|date=14 May 1923|page=8|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> to showcase the [[Solar eclipse of March 28, 1922|Eclipse of 1922]].
A very young Sir [[Charles Kingsford-Smith]] was the pilot of the Western Australian Airways [[Bristol Tourer|Bristol]] Type 28 Coupe Tourers plane (G-AUDF) that made bi-weekly mail drops to the Astronomers during the expedition.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/23875584|title=Aviation|work=The West Australian|location=Perth, West Australia|date=29 September 1922|page=7|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Kingsford-Smith took Brandon-Cremer aloft to shoot aerial footage of the camp, which was later used in the film previously mentioned.
<gallery style="margin:auto;"> File:EBC Biplane1922.jpg|Brandon-Cremer self taken image along side Kingsford-Smiths biplane at Wallal File:Charles Kingsford-Smith at Wallal.jpg|Charles Kingsford-Smith at Wallal File:Lick_Eclipse.jpg|1922 Solar eclipse photographic plate taken at Wallal File:Eclipse Marker at Wallal, Western Australia.jpg|Eclipse Marker at Wallal, Western Australia </gallery>
== The 1920s and aerial exploits == During the 1920s Brandon-Cremer was working for Paramount Studios in Australia as a cameraman and filmmaker, he produced such films as 'Java: The Garden of the East' (only the script exists of this movie); Other films included 'Nursery Rhymes' with his father at Bronte Beach, Sydney and 'British Quality Triumphant' in 1925. A film about automobiles, motorcycles, trucks, tractors and aircraft built in Britain and transported for sale in Australia.
On 15 July 1925, Brandon-Cremer married a second time to Sara Inez Vera Bell in [[Queensland]]. Sara lost a newborn son, Anthony Brandon-Cremer on 14 March 1926, also in Queensland. The marriage dissolved shortly after.
Brandon-Cremer was active in covering aviation news and filming scenes in flight. He was instrumental in covering the arrival of the [[Southern Cross (aircraft)|Southern Cross]] on its journey on the first Trans-Pacific flight to Australia in 1928, piloted by his friend Charles Kingsford-Smith.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/115414591|title=Film Scoop|work=Evening News|location=Sydney, New South Wales|date=12 June 1928|page=17|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Later that year while covering the arrival of the 'British Super-marines' of the Royal Air Force from London to Sydney, he and his pilot Sturt Griffith ditched into [[Port Jackson|Sydney Harbour]]. Both men suffered minor injuries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/57059950|title=Plane Accident|work=The Register|location=Adelaide, South Australia|date=2 August 1928|page=9|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Six months later Brandon-Cremer was the observer for Gypsy-Moth deliveries between Melbourne and Sydney.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/16528024|title=Gypsy-Moth 'Plane|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|location=New South Wales|date=2 February 1929|page=16|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Another newspaper article mentions his participation on filming the departure of the aeroplane 'Canberra' ([[de Havilland Giant Moth]]), An aerial expedition sent out to find the missing 'Southern Cross', piloted by Kingsford-Smith, on its attempted trip from Sydney to London.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/222963652|title=Canberra Film|work=The Sun|location=Sydney, New South Wales|date=10 July 1929|page=15|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Finally, Brandon-Cremer was included in a ride along on the [[Vickers Vellore|Vellore]] aeroplane journey from London to Sydney.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/233117111|title=Paramount News|work=The Magnet Mirror and Murchison Reflector|date=11 April 1929|page=1|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
[[File:1930 Cinesound studios and Crew.jpg|thumb|Ernest Brandon-Cremer with the Cinesound crew Bondi Junction 1930]] == Cinesound newsreels, 1930s == Brandon-Cremer worked for the newsreel producers [[Cinesound]] during the 1930s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/41201916|title=Cinesound Newsreel|work=Cairns Post|location=Queensland|date=3 August 1933|page=6|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://colsearch.nfsa.gov.au/nfsa/search/display/display.w3p;adv=;group=;groupequals=;holdingType=digital%3D1070;page=0;parentid=;query=Bud%20Cramer;querytype=;rec=0;resCount=10|title=Cinesound's Camera and sound crew|location=Bondi studio|year=1930|via=National Film and Sound Archive}}</ref>
[[Cinesound]] was a competitor to [[Movietone News]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/118204047|title=Nostalgic Look at Australian Films|work=The Canberra Times|date=10 February 1986|page=25|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> The [[Cinesound]] studio was based in Bondi Junction, Sydney.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/151993993|title=Cinesound Films|work=Mayborough Chronicle|date=15 December 1934|page=8|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
The [[Cinesound]] cadre of cinematographers included Bill Carty, Joe Stafford, Arthur Smith, Bert Cross, Frank Bagnell, Clive Cross, [[Frank Coffey]], [[George Heath (cinematographer)|George Heath]], [[Frank Hurley]], Stan Murdoch, Bill Shepherd and George Malcolm.
== Lasseter's Reef of Gold, 1931 == The gold prospector [[Lewis Harold Bell Lasseter]] had become famous by telling the story of his outback survival and discovery of a massive reef of surface gold near [[Uluru]], Northern Territory. Members of the Sydney Stock Exchange organised the 'Central Australian Gold Exploration' Company (CAGE) to venture outback and rediscover this find.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/224264190|title=New Company|work=The Sun|location=Sydney, New South Wales|date=24 June 1930|page=12|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/46589781|title=Central Australian Gold Exploration Co., Ltd|work=Barrier Miner|location=Broken Hill, New South Wales|date=23 July 1930|page=2|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Camel trains and aircraft were sent out to scour the surrounds. One night during the expedition, Lasseter on camelback disappeared into the dark. After a futile search the party returned to Sydney.
A second Expedition was organised called CAGE-II.<ref name="Gold Quest">{{cite news|url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/2253153|title=Gold Quest|work=The Canberra Times|location=Australian Capital Territory|date=17 August 1931|page=2|via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> In August 1931, while working for Cinesound, 'Bud' signed-on with the Central Australian Gold Exploration Company (CAGE-II) to produce all the photography and a documentary film for a search party expedition to attempt to find Lasseter and his fabled reef of gold. The party to be led by local Bob Buck, a close friend of Brandon-Cremer.
The party left [[Alice Springs]] on Camel back en route to Uluru and the Western Ranges. A few hundred kilometres west of Uluru they discovered a tree with inscriptions and directions, left by Lasseter, to a river and cave. Upon digging a short while, Buck and Brandon-Cremer discovered the bones of [[Lewis Harold Bell Lasseter|Harold Lasseter]], and his diary. A subsequent search did not find the fabled reef of gold. The story has become Australian folklore and some still believe the reef of gold exists.<ref>http://www.theaustralian.com.au/arts/review/luke-walker-digs-up-a-hot-prospect-with-lasseters-bones/story-fn9n8gph-1226741606541</ref>
Some of Brandon-Cremer's photos were later published in the chronicle of [[Lasseter's Last Ride]] by [[Ion Idriess|Ion L. Idriess]]. The Mitchell Library in Sydney retains some of the photos taken during the expedition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archival.sl.nsw.gov.au/Details/archive/110045082|title=John Bailey collection of photographs showing Bob Buck leading the expedition to recover Lasseter's body in Central Australia|via=State Library of New South Wales}}</ref>
Prior to the CAGE-II Expedition as it was called, 'Bud' was credited in the ''Sydney Sunday Guardian'', in August 1931 – "Mr. Ernest Brandon-Cremer is the photographer. A complete moving picture record of the expedition's activities is to be taken by Mr. Cremer, who comes from Hollywood."<ref name="Gold Quest" /> He was also referenced for this Lasseter connection in the Horden House ''Encyclopedia of Exploration''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hordern.com/explorers-encyclopedia/encyclopedia-of-exploration-4-people.php|title=Encyclopedia of Exploration 1850 to 1940|publisher=Hordern House}}</ref>
[[File:EBC History timeline.png|thumb|History timeline]] == Partial filmography ==
* "Java: The Garden of the East" (1922) – Travelogue (film missing) * "Astronomers and Aboriginees" (1922) – Western Australian Solar Eclipse Documentary * "British Quality Triumphant" (1925) – Showcase of Automobiles & Aircraft * "Nursery Rhymes" (1929) – Children's film with Albert Brandon-Cremer (Bronte Beach, Sydney) * "Lasseter's Gold" (1931) – Documentary * "Queensland: Its Places and People" (1933) – Travelogue * "In and Around Mackay: By Land, Sea and Air" (1933) – Travelogue * "Arnhem Land" (1933) – script produced, permission was not granted by Canberra to make this film.

{{Refimprove|date=December 2008}} '''Go! Comi''' was the publishing imprint of the [[United States|American]] multimedia company, [[Go! Media Entertainment]], LLC,<ref>http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2005-05-14/new-manga-publisher-announced-go-media-entertainment</ref> established to "specializ(e) in publishing Japanese comics for the American market, and in creating new manga and manga-oriented properties for both the Japanese and American markets."<ref>http://www.gocomi.com/</ref>
==History==
Go! Comi was launched in 2005.<ref>http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2005-05-14/new-manga-publisher-announced-go-media-entertainment</ref> They published such best-selling series as the Eisner-nominated ''[[After School Nightmare]]'', ''[[Cantarella (manga)|Cantarella]]'', ''[[Her Majesty's Dog]]'', ''[[Tenshi Ja Nai]]!!'' and ''[[Crossroad (manga)|Crossroad]]''. The company's CEO was television writer [[David Wise (writer)|David Wise]].
The imprint was shut down during the manga bust that followed the recession.<ref>http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/comics/article/56693-manga-2013-a-smaller-more-sustainable-market.html</ref> The official website stopped being updated in early 2010 and expired in May of that year.<ref>http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2010-05-11/go-comi-lets-its-website-expire</ref>
In 2011, the site was relaunched under new owners with instructions to donate to a PayPal account to revive the publisher, but former Go! Comi Creative Director Audry Taylor confirmed that the new website was a scam not associated with the defunct imprint.<ref>http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2011-05-12/go-comi-former-site-relaunched-under-false-pretenses</ref>

Vision |volume=6 |issue=8 |page=106 |date=August 2007 |issn=1541-4817 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |first=Jason |last=Thompson |author-link=Jason Thompson (writer) |url=http://www.unboundworlds.com/2010/03/365-days-of-manga-day-183-kanna/ |title=365 Days of Manga, Day 183: Kanna! |work=Unbound Worlds |date=March 17, 2010 }}<!-- https://web.archive.org/web/20100420054059/http://www.suvudu.com/2010/03/365-days-of-manga-day-183-kanna.html --></ref> *''[[King of the Lamp]]'' *''[[Kurogane Communication]]''<ref>http://www.gocomi.com/category/kurogane-communication/</ref> *''[[Love Master A]]'' *''[[Night of the Beasts]]''<ref>http://www.gocomi.com/category/night-of-the-beasts/</ref> *''[[Song of the Hanging Sky]]'' *''[[Tenshi Ja Nai]]'' *''[[The Devil Within (manga)|The Devil Within]]''<ref>http://www.gocomi.com/category/devil-within/</ref> *''[[Three in Love]]'' *''[[Train+Train]]'' *''[[Yggdrasil (manga)]]'' *''[[Ultimate Venus]]''<ref>http://www.gocomi.com/category/ultimate-venus/</ref>

A '''Gramogram''' or '''Grammagram''' or '''Letteral Word''' is a letter or group of letters which can be pronounced to form one or more words, as in "CU" for "See you".<ref name="high">{{cite web|title=Cryptic crossword reference lists > Gramograms|url=http://www.highlightpress.com.au/gramograms.html|publisher=Highlight Press|accessdate=31 December 2016}}</ref><ref name=deal /><ref>{{cite web|title=Grammagrams|url=https://www.wordnik.com/lists/grammagrams|website=Wordnik|accessdate=31 December 2016}}</ref> They are a subset of [[rebus]]es,<ref name=anil /> and are commonly misunderstood for abbreviations.{{cn|date=December 2016}}
They are commonly used as a component of [[cryptic crossword]] clues.<ref name=high />
A poem reportedly appeared in the ''[[Woman's Home Companion]]'' of July 1903 using many grammagrams: it was preceded by the line "ICQ out so that I can CU have fun translating the sound FX of this poem".<ref name=deal>{{cite web|title=Grammagrams|url=http://www.audreydeal.co.uk/testlink|publisher=Audrey Deal|accessdate=31 December 2016}}</ref>
A restaurant scene where a customer initially asks "FUNEX" ("Have you any eggs") appears in a 1949 book ''Hail fellow well met'' by [[Seymour Hicks]]<ref name="hicks">{{cite book|last1=Hicks|first1=Sir Seymour|title=Hail Fellow Well Met|date=1949|publisher=Staples Press|page=183|url=https://books.google.com/?id=fWUqAAAAMAAJ&q=%22have+you+any+eggs%22+funex&dq=%22have+you+any+eggs%22+funex|accessdate=31 December 2016}}</ref> and was performed in ''[[The Two Ronnies]]'' under the title ''Swedish made simple''.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Brennan|first1=Ailis|title=Ronnie Corbett dies: Here are his funniest seven sketches|url=http://www.gq-magazine.co.uk/article/ronnie-corbett-funniest-sketches|publisher=GQ|accessdate=31 December 2016}}</ref>
The book ''How to Double the Meaning of Life'' devotes three pages to gramograms, to which the author, Anil, gives the name '''Letteral words'''.<ref name="anil">{{cite book|last1=Anil|title=How to Double the Meaning of Life|publisher=Xlibris|isbn=9781462871209|pages=237–239|chapter-url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=60MeAwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA237&ots=1XBcOP65ST&dq=gramogram%20meaning&pg=PA237#v=onepage&q=gramogram%20meaning&f=false|accessdate=31 December 2016|chapter=Letteral Words|year=2011}}</ref>
{{As of|December 2016}} neither spelling of the word appears in the online ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]''.
Some are homophones because some can be used for multiple words.

{{cite check|date=July 2018}} The '''history of Korean animation''', the manipulation of images to make them appear as moving, began with Japanese and American characters dominating the industry. The first sound animated character was created in 1936. The first feature-length animated character appeared in 1967. [[Dooly the Little Dinosaur]] revolutionized the character market in 1987. As animation characters specific to Korea appeared, the Korean character market continued to grow. Since then, Korean character franchises have even exported their characters to other countries.
== History == [[File:Pororo statues in Lotte world 2 Seoul South Korea.jpg|thumb|Pororo with Petty in [[Lotte World II Hotel]]]] [[File:Animation character Lava.jpg|thumb|Larva in the [[Lotte World II Hotel]]]] [[File:타요버스 9401 가니 A01.JPG|thumb|Tayo bus 'Gani']] [[File:루돌프 타요.JPG|thumb|Tayo bus 'Rudolph']] Han Chang-Wan, a professor at [[Sejong University]], published the history of animation character design in Korea at the Character Licensing Fair 2016. This study became the first to have rabbit and turtle illustrations as Korean animated characters. This was revealed in '[[Tongnip Sinmun|The Independent]]' newspaper.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.msn.com/ko-kr/news/other/%ED%95%9C%EA%B5%AD-%EC%BA%90%EB%A6%AD%ED%84%B0-%EB%B3%80%EC%B2%9C%EC%82%AC%EB%A5%BC-%EC%82%B4%ED%94%BC%EB%8B%A4%E2%80%A6%EC%BA%90%EB%A6%AD%ED%84%B0%C2%B7%EB%9D%BC%EC%9D%B4%EC%84%A0%EC%8B%B1-%ED%8E%98%EC%96%B4/ar-BBujYiL|title=한국 캐릭터 변천사를 살피다…'캐릭터·라이선싱 페어'|last=Gu|first=Jungmo|date=2016-07-14|work=|publisher=MSN|publication-date=2016-07-14|trans-title=The history of Korean character...'Character·licensing fair'|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
According to records, the first sound animated character was 'Gaekkum' (개꿈), who was created in 1936. This first feature-length animated character appeared in 1967, in the namesake movie about a character named [[Hong Gildong jeon|Hong Gildong]] (홍길동).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://movie.naver.com/movie/magazine/magazine.nhn?nid=1270|title=한국 애니메이션 베스트 15|last=Kim|first=Hyungseok|date=2011-12-08|work=|publisher=Naver movie|publication-date=2011-12-08|trans-title=Best 15 of Korean animation|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
With American and Japanese characters dominating the Korean animation industry until the 1970s, it wasn't until 1983 when Dooly the Little Dinosaur (아기 공룡 둘리) appeared in Bomulsum—a monthly magazine for kids—and changed the Korean character market.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://blog.daum.net/mocie/15613209|title=황글알을 낳는 거위! 떠오르는 '한국 캐릭터 산업'|last=Korean Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy|first=Official blog|date=2013-04-19|work=|publisher=Korean Ministry of Trade, Industry and Energy|publication-date=2013-04-19|trans-title=The golden goose! Growing Korean character industries|access-date=|via=}}</ref> In 1987, Dooly the Little Dinosaur first aired as a six-part TV show, with another seven parts airing in 1988. In 1995, [[Kim Soo-jung]], its creator, established a company named 'Dooly World' and went into the character design industry. The following year, the animated movie '[[Dooly the Little Dinosaur]]' was released. In the 30 years since Dooly the Little Dinosaur launched, its related market generated 2–3 billion [[South Korean won|won]] per year (about 1.7–2.7 million dollars as of July 2018). This paved the way for the character market in Korea.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://biz.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2013/04/30/2013043002012.html|title='둘리' 이후 30년…캐릭터 시장 규모 8조원 육박'|last=No|first=Jawoon|date=2013-05-01|work=|publisher=Chosun Biz|publication-date=2013-05-01|trans-title=30 years after 'Dooly'… The size of Character market is closing in upon 8 trillion won|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
In 2003, [[Pororo the Little Penguin]] (뽀롱뽀롱 뽀로로) aired on [[Educational Broadcasting System|EBS]] and became the new representation of Korean animation characters. Pororo aired in 127 countries around the world and was the first domestic animation to make a contract with [[Walt Disney Animation Studios]] directly. It was estimated that its brand value was worth 850 billion won (about 750 million dollars) and its economic impact amounted to 5.7 trillion won (about 5 billion dollars) in 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.businesspost.co.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=1735|title=뽀로로는 왜 세계적 캐릭터가 됐을까|last=Choi|first=Yonghyeok|date=2014-05-02|work=|publisher=Business Post|publication-date=2014-05-02|trans-title=Why Pororo can be world wide character|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
Currently, many other domestic Korean animations have gained popularity, such as [[Tobot]] (변신자동차 또봇), [[Larva (TV series)]] (라바), and [[Tayo the Little Bus]] (꼬마버스 타요).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.edaily.co.kr/news/NewsRead.edy?SCD=JI71&newsid=01200486609466992&DCD=A407&OutLnkChk=Y|title='뽀로로'…130개국 수출 경제효과 6조 육박|last=Lee|first=Yoonjung|date=2015-08-13|work=|publisher=E daily|publication-date=2015-08-13|trans-title='Pororo'…Export for 130 countries around the world|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
The animated [[Larva (TV series)]] (라바) recorded 10 billion won (about 9 million dollars) in sales in 2013. In addition, domestic characters such as [[Tayo the Little Bus]] have earned considerable sales due to the support of young children.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://biz.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2013/04/30/2013043002012.html|title='둘리' 이후 30년…캐릭터 시장 규모 8조원 육박'|last=No|first=Jawoon|date=2013-05-01|work=|publisher=Chosun Biz|publication-date=2013-05-01|trans-title=30 years after 'Dooly'… The size of Character market is closing in upon 8 trillion won|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
== Transition in character production methods == In the 1980s–1990s, cartoon characters expanded mainly because:
* comic books were popular. * the characters of this period had great stories. * the symbolism in the images.<ref name=":24">{{Cite journal|last=Hyeyoung Chu, hyunju Lee, Hyehyun Cho, Mirae Hwang|first=|date=Winter 2014|title=Periodic Features of Korean Character Designs|url=http://aodr.org/xml/01492/01492.pdf|journal=3.1 Period of Published Cartoon Characters (1980s~1990s)|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
Between 2000 and 2010, Flash characters became prevalent in Korea because:
* they facilitated production. In the files, scaling doen't affect quality and are much smaller, which increases speed of transmission. * their popularity and rapid dissemination online. * story lines were aimed not only at children but also at adults.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=Hyeyoung Chu, hyunju Lee, Hyehyun Cho, Mirae Hwang|first=|date=Winter 2014|title=Periodic Features of Korean Character Designs|url=http://aodr.org/xml/01492/01492.pdf|journal=3.2 Period of Two-Dimensional Flash Animated Characters (The early 2000s)|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
Later in the decade, 3D animations were mainly done with 3D STUDIO MAX or MAYA software<ref name=":32">OSMU is a kind of sales strategy that develops contents service on various media such as book, movie and game. It is referred to as Media franchise in America and Media mix in Japan.</ref> and their production costs are much greater than for 2D Flash animations.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Hyeyoung Chu, Hyunju Lee, Hyehyun Cho, Mirae Hwang|first=|date=Winter 2014|title=Periodic Features of Korean Character Designs|url=http://aodr.org/xml/01492/01492.pdf|journal=3.3. Period of Three-dimensional Animation Characters (the mid-2000s)|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hyeyoung Chu, hyunju Lee, Hyehyun Cho, Mirae Hwang|first=|date=Winter 2014|title=Periodic Features of Korean Character Designs|url=http://aodr.org/xml/01492/01492.pdf|journal=3. Classification of domestically-produced characters based on media formats|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>

(‘라바’를 ‘타요’, 어디서?)] Article published in 2014 by the Seoul government.

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Use British English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox television | show_name = How Videogames Changed the World | image = How Videogames Changed the World.png | genre = [[Entertainment]] | writer = [[Charlie Brooker]]
[[Matt Lees]]
Jon Blyth
Cara Ellison | presenter = Charlie Brooker | theme_music_composer = Jonathan Dunn | opentheme = ''[[RoboCop (1988 video game)|Robocop]]'' theme | endtheme = ''[[RoboCop (1988 video game)|Robocop]]'' theme | country = United Kingdom | language = English | runtime = 97 minutes | company = Zeppotron | distributor = [[Endemol UK]] | picture_format = [[16:9]] | first_run = {{start date|df=y|2013|11|30}} | channel = [[Channel 4]] }} '''''How Videogames Changed the World''''' is a one-off [[television special]] by [[Charlie Brooker]] which was aired on [[Channel 4]] in November 2013. The show examines the 25 most significant [[video games]] according to Brooker, and through that, covers the [[History of video games|history of the medium]] and its impact on wider culture. == Pundits featured == * [[Jonathan Ross]] * [[Jeff Minter]] * Keith Stuart * [[Peter Serafinowicz]] * [[Tom Watson (Labour politician)]] * [[Peter Molyneux]] * Aoife Wilson (writer for ''[[Official Xbox Magazine]]'') * Rob Florence * [[Kate Russell (reporter)]] * [[Graham Linehan]] * [[Dara Ó Briain]] * [[Gary Whitta]] * [[David Braben]] * Ellie Gibson (journalist for ''[[Eurogamer]]'') * [[Labrinth]] * [[Felicia Day]] * Keza MacDonald * [[Pete Donaldson]] * Berni Goode (cyber-psychologist) * [[Tim Schafer]] * [[Neil Druckmann]] * [[Ron Gilbert]] * Susan Calman (comedian) * [[John Romero]] * [[Rhianna Pratchett]] * [[Matt Lees]] * Quintin Smith (then-journalist for [[Eurogamer]]) * [[Will Wright (game designer)]] * [[Malorie Blackman]] * [[Nolan Bushnell]] * [[Vince Zampella]] Pundits Aoife Wilson,Keza Mac Donald,Quintin Smith and show writer Jon Blythe would later make several appearances on the podcast Daft Souls hosted by show writer and pundit Matt Lees. ==List of games== {{colbegin}} {{ordered list | item1_value=25 | ''[[Pong]]'' (1972) | item2_value=24 | ''[[Space Invaders]]'' (1978) | item3_value=23 | ''[[Pac-Man]]'' (1980) | item4_value=22 | ''[[Manic Miner]]'' (1983) | item5_value=21 | ''[[Elite (video game)|Elite]]'' (1984) | item6_value=20 | ''[[Super Mario Bros.]]'' (1985) | item7_value=19 | ''[[Tetris]]'' (1986) | item8_value=18 | ''[[The Secret of Monkey Island]]'' (1990) | item9_value=17 | ''[[Street Fighter II]]'' (1991) | item10_value=16 | ''[[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]]'' (1993) | item11_value=15 | ''[[Night Trap]]'' (1992) | item12_value=14 | ''[[Tomb Raider (1996 video game)|Tomb Raider]]'' (1996) | item13_value=13 | ''[[PaRappa the Rapper]]'' (1997) | item14_value=12 | ''[[StarCraft (video game)|StarCraft]]'' (1998) | item15_value=11 | ''[[The Sims (video game)|The Sims]]'' (2000) | item16_value=10 | ''[[Grand Theft Auto III]]'' (2001) | item17_value=9 | ''[[Shadow of the Colossus]]'' (2006) | item18_value=8 | ''[[World of Warcraft]]'' (2005) | item19_value=7 | ''[[Wii Sports]]'' (2006) | item20_value=6 | ''[[Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare]]'' (2007) | item21_value=5 | ''[[Braid (video game)|Braid]]'' (2008) | item22_value=4 | ''[[Angry Birds (video game)|Angry Birds]]'' (2009) | item23_value=3 | ''[[Minecraft]]'' (2011) | item24_value=2 | ''[[The Last of Us]]'' (2013) | item25_value=1 | ''[[Twitter]]'' }} {{colend}} ==Reception== Dan Whitehead, in a review for [[Eurogamer]], found the selection of games well chosen, enabling the show to cover the history of video games as fully as possible given its runtime. He also praised the choice of [[pundit]]s, highlighting that even the most recognisable of names, such as [[Jonathan Ross]] and [[Peter Serafinowicz]], were included because they had a clear love of games and not for their celebrity appeal. Whitehead concluded that the show was a success, fun and informative, but also hampered by the format - having to cover the entirety of video gaming history in one show to an unfamiliar audience, a symptom of the lack of video games representation on television. Keith Stuart, who appeared on the show, reflected on its merits in a column for ''[[The Guardian]]''. Stuart described how ending the show with Twitter was a clever way of showing how [[gamification]] has infiltrated everyday lives, with social networks relying on the same reward systems as video games. Stuart liked how the show featured games like ''[[Papers, Please]]'', a game that explores guilt and the nature of evil, which helped to remove misconceptions that video games are incapable of exploring real-world issues. Like Whitehead, Stuart concluded with a lament over the lack of video games coverage on television, criticising broadcasters for "ceding responsibility to [[YouTube]]rs and specialist online documentary makers" and for "failing their audiences". Sam Wollaston, also writing for ''[[The Guardian]]'', gave a mixed review and was critical of the [[Pundit|talking heads]] format. Wollaston commented that despite containing interesting ideas, the show was overly long. For [[gamer]]s however, Wollaston wrote that the show "would have been pretty much heaven". ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite web| url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-12-05-tv-review-how-videogames-changed-the-world| title=TV review: How Videogames Changed the World| author=Dan Whitehead| work=[[Eurogamer]]| date=5 December 2013| accessdate=7 December 2013}} {{cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2013/dec/02/how-video-games-changed-the-world-some-thoughts| title=How Video Games Changed the World – some thoughts| author=Keith Stuart| work=[[The Guardian]]| date=2 December 2013| accessdate=7 December 2013}} {{cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2013/dec/02/secret-life-of-mary-poppins-tv-review| title=The Secret Life of Mary Poppins; How Video Games Changed the World – TV review| author=Sam Wollaston| work=[[The Guardian]]| date=2 December 2013| accessdate=7 December 2013}} }} ==External links== *[http://www.channel4.com/programmes/charlie-brooker-videogames-changed-the-world ''How Videogames Changed the World''] on [[Channel 4]] *{{imdb title|3297108}} {{Charlie Brooker}} [[Category:2013 in British television]] [[Category:2013 television specials]] [[Category:Channel 4 television programmes]] [[Category:Television series created by Charlie Brooker]] [[Category:Documentary films about video games]] [[Category:Television programs about video games]] [[Category:Television series by Endemol]] [[Category:Television series by Zeppotron]] [[Category:Video gaming in the United Kingdom]]

{{about||the magical curse|Jinx|the bird genus|Wryneck|other uses|Jynx (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox video game character |name = Jynx |image = Pokémon Jynx (purple) art.png |caption = '''[[List of Pokémon|National Pokédex]]'''
[[Scyther]] -''' Jynx (#124)''' - [[Electabuzz]] |series = [[Pokémon (video game series)|''Pokémon'' series]] |firstgame = [[Pokémon Red and Blue|''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'']] |artist = [[Ken Sugimori]] |voiceactor = {{Vgrelease|[[English language|EN]]|[[Rachael Lillis]]|[[Japanese language|JP]]|[[Mayumi Tanaka]]}} }} '''Jynx''', known in Japan as {{nihongo|'''Rougela'''|ルージュラ|Rūjura}}, is a [[List of Pokémon|Pokémon species]] in [[Nintendo]] and [[Game Freak]]'s ''[[Pokémon]]'' franchise. Created by [[Ken Sugimori]], Jynx first appeared in the video games [[Pokémon Red and Blue|''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'']] and subsequent sequels, later appearing in various merchandise, spinoff titles, or animated and printed adaptations of the franchise. The character is voiced in Japanese by [[Mayumi Tanaka]] and by [[Rachael Lillis]] in English. Jynx's design and humanoid appearance has been heavily criticized by the Western media, most notably by cultural critic [[Carole Boston Weatherford]], who described Jynx as representing [[blackface]] after seeing the character's depiction in the anime. Due to complaints, Game Freak modified its appearance by changing the original color of its face from black to the current color, purple. ==Design and characteristics== Jynx was one of 151 different designs conceived by Game Freak's character development team and finalized by [[Ken Sugimori]] for the first generation of ''Pocket Monsters'' games ''Red'' and ''Green'', which were localized outside Japan as [[Pokémon Red and Blue|''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'']].{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/ds/interview/irbj/vol1/index2.html|title=2. 一新されたポケモンの世界|page=2|work=Nintendo.com|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|accessdate=2018-01-04|language=ja}}{{cite web|url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=91965|title=Game Freak on Pokémon!|author=Stuart Bishop|work=[[Computer and Video Games|CVG]]|date=2003-05-30|accessdate=2008-02-07|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5VSJaR6xT?url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=91965|archivedate=2008-02-08}} Originally called "Rujura" in Japanese, Nintendo decided to give the various Pokémon species "clever and descriptive names" related to their appearance or features, when translating the game for western audiences, as a means to make the characters more relatable to American children.{{cite news|url=https://edition.cnn.com/ASIANOW/time/magazine/99/1122/cover2.html|title=PokéMania|author1=Howard Chua-Euan|author2=Tim Larimer|date=1999-11-22|volume=154|number=20|journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|agency=[[CNN]]|accessdate=2018-01-04}} As a result, they were renamed "Jynx", a play on the word "[[jinx]]".{{cite web|url=http://guidesarchive.ign.com/guides/12045/jynx.html|title=#124: Jynx|website=[[IGN]]|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|accessdate=2018-01-04}} Also known as the "Human Shape" Pokémon, Jynx is a female-only species that resembles the Japanese mythical creatures [[Yamauba]] and [[Yuki-onna]]. Originally portrayed with a black face and hands, Jynx's design was changed to purple coloration after critiques that it perpetuated racism. In addition Jynx have large pink lips, [[saucer]]-like eyes, white arms, and long, [[blond]] hair. The "clothes" they appear to wear are actually part of their body, resembling a circular red [[Brassiere|bra]] and [[skirt]]. Jynx have no visible feet, and in the games leave no footprints. Jynx has a pre-evolution, [[Smoochum]], which evolves into Jynx when it receives enough [[Experience point|experience]] from battles and reaches level 30. Jynx Pokémon walk in a dance-like fashion, wiggling their hips in a manner described by Nintendo as "seductive".{{Pokédex|red|It seductively wiggles its hips as it walks. It can cause people to dance in unison with it.}} It uses dancing to communicate, with the exact rhythm relying on its emotion at the time. The dance affects people, causing them to themselves dance with no regard to their actions.{{Pokédex|ruby|Jynx walks rhythmically, swaying and shaking its hips as if it were dancing. Its motions are so bouncingly alluring, people seeing it are compelled to shake their hips without giving any thought to what they are doing}} Jynx speak in a language that only other Jynx can understand, though the sound is described as similar to human speech.{{Pokédex|diamond|Its cries sound like human speech. However, it is impossible to tell what it is trying to say.}} This trait is carried on to games where Pokémon speak English such as the ''[[Pokémon Mystery Dungeon]]'' series, with the text appearing as combinations of [[Hugs and kisses|"X"s, "O"s]], [[punctuation marks]], and/or musical notes, instead of legible words.{{cite video game|title=[[Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Blue Rescue Team and Red Rescue Team|''Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Blue Rescue Team'' and ''Red Rescue Team'']]|developer=Chunsoft|publisher=Nintendo|date=2006-09-18|platform=Nintendo DS|quote=∞XO@#*~♪♪♪}} Jynx are [[psychic]], and can attack either by kissing an opponent or launching "strange orbs" at them, and can protect themselves with a psychically-generated barrier.{{cite video game|title=[[Pokémon Ranger]]|developer=HAL Laboratory|publisher=Nintendo|date=2006-10-30|platform=Nintendo DS|quote=Jynx swings its hips as if it's dancing while walking. Beware of its kiss attack!}}{{cite video game|title=[[Pokémon Ranger: Shadows of Almia]]|developer=[[Creatures (company)|Creatures Inc.]]|publisher=Nintendo|date=2008-11-10|platform=Nintendo DS|quote=It attacks by launching strange orbs. It protects itself with a psychic barrier.}} ==Appearances== ===In video games=== In [[Pokémon Red and Blue|''Pokémon Red'' and ''Blue'']] and their remakes, [[Pokémon FireRed and LeafGreen|''Pokémon FireRed'' and ''LeafGreen'']], Jynx is a rare Pokémon that is only available through trading with an [[Non-player character|in-game NPC]]. In addition, the Kanto Elite Four member [[List of Pokémon characters#Kanto Elite Four|Lorelei]] uses a Jynx on her team. Jynx appears in the wild in [[Pokémon Gold and Silver|''Pokémon Gold'' and ''Silver'']], ''[[Pokémon Platinum]]'', [[Pokémon HeartGold and SoulSilver|''Pokémon HeartGold'' and ''SoulSilver'']], and [[Pokémon X and Y|''Pokémon X'' and ''Y'']].{{cite web|url=http://guidesarchive.ign.com/guides/12865/pokedexloc.html|title=Pokémon Locations Listing|website=IGN|publisher=News Corporation|accessdate=2018-01-04}} Because of the controversy of Jynx's skin, it was changed from black to purple in ''[[Pokémon Stadium 2]]'' and all later games. Jynx is the evolved form of [[Smoochum]].{{cite web|url=http://guidesarchive.ign.com/guides/12865/8.html|title=Walkthrough - Ice Path|website=IGN|publisher=News Corporation|accessdate=2018-01-04}} Outside of the main series, Jynx appeared in ''[[Pokémon Snap]]'', ''[[Pokémon Pinball]]'', [[Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Explorers of Time and Explorers of Darkness|''Pokémon Mystery Dungeon: Explorers of Time'' and ''Explorers of Darkness'']], and the ''[[Pokémon Ranger]]'' games. ===In anime=== Jynx first appeared in the [[Pokémon (anime)|Pokémon anime]] in ''[[Holiday Hi-Jynx]]'' when one of Santa Claus's Jynx was separated from him, [[Ash Ketchum|Ash]] and friends helped to return the Jynx to her owner.{{cite episode|title=Holiday Hi-Jynx|series=[[Pokémon (anime)|Pokémon]]|credits=Hideki Sonoda (writer)|network=Various|airdate=1999-12-11|season=1|number=63}} The episode was not re-aired in USA because of the controversy over her appearance. However, it was placed on On-Demand on 2011, so people who live in USA could have easily viewed it then. Jynx appeared again in the episode ''[[The Ice Cave]]'',{{cite episode|title=The Ice Cave|series=[[Pokémon (anime)|Pokémon]]|credits=Yukiyoshi Ōhashi (writer)|network=Various|airdate=2002-05-30|season=3|number=250}} which was not aired in English-speaking countries for the same reason. Jynx also made a cameo as a doll that Misty wins.{{cite episode|title=Princess vs. Princess|series=[[Pokémon (anime)|Pokémon]]|credits=Junki Takegami (writer)|network=Various|airdate=1999-09-04|season=1|number=52}} Jynx later appears in ''Pokémon Orange Islands'' series, in episodes still present in American rotations. Jynx made an appearance in a contest in ''All Things Bright and Beautifly''.{{cite episode|title=All Things Bright and Beautifly|series=[[Pokémon (anime)|Pokémon]]|credits=Atsuhiro Tomioka (writer)|network=Various|airdate=2003-12-27|season=6|number=286}} However, because Jynx had been animated with black skin instead of purple, her 13-second appearance was cut from the English dub. Jynx later appears in episodes 116 and 117 of ''[[Pokémon: Advanced Generation]]'', with the inoffensive purple skin color.{{cite episode|title=Pacifidlog Jam|series=[[Pokémon (anime)|Pokémon]]|credits=Aya Matsui (writer)|network=Various|airdate=2006-04-08|season=6|number=116}}{{cite episode|title=Berry, Berry Interesting|series=[[Pokémon (anime)|Pokémon]]|credits=Masashi Sogo (writer)|network=Various|airdate=2006-02-11|season=6|number=117}} Because the main order of these episodes would have been during February which is also [[Black History Month]], KidsWB chose to air these episodes out of order and air them in April after the Hoenn Championship League episodes as it would help build the ratings with the Grand Festival and Hoenn League episodes and it would have avoided offending people during February due to the Jynx controversy. However one exception was in the episode ''Hi Ho Silver Wind!'' where a purple Jynx had a minor cameo which aired in February.{{cite episode|title=Hi Ho Silver Wind!|series=[[Pokémon (anime)|Pokémon]]|credits=Atsuhiro Tomioka (writer)|network=Various|airdate=2006-02-18|season=6|number=121}} These episodes were aired in the normal rotational order in the UK. A trio of Jynx sisters were later depicted in the episode ''Three Jynx and a Baby''. These three Jynx were overly-protective towards their sister, a Smoochum. The Smoochum evolved into a Jynx at the end of the episode.{{cite episode|title=Three Jynx and a Baby|series=[[Pokémon (anime)|Pokémon]]|credits=Junki Takegami (writer)|network=Various|airdate=2006-11-25|season=9|number=440}} ===In printed material=== Jynx's most notable role in the [[Pokémon manga]] is being under the ownership of [[Lorelei (Pokémon)|Lorelei]] in [[Pokémon Adventures]]. Lorelei's Jynx is noted for having the ability to generate voodoo dolls out of ice using its Ice Beam. When Lorelei draws crosses on any part of the dolls using her lipstick, ice shackles form on the specified body parts of her targets, eventually freezing the victim over completely. Even after the victims are broken free, the freeze induces lasting numbness in the areas where it was applied. Both [[Red (Pokémon)|Red]] and [[Sabrina (Pokémon)|Sabrina]] suffered this condition and had to seek a cure atop Mt. Silver by bathing in the hotsprings there. Another ability of Lorelei's Jynx is revealed in the Sevii Islands saga: she can create a wispy band of ice around targets, with which Lorelei can use to track down using her powder case. Jynx has made a number of appearances in the ''[[Pokémon Trading Card Game]]'', with the black-skinned design (sometimes US version cards show up purple and edited before the controversy) before the Weatherford controversy, and with the purple-skinned design after Nintendo regained control of the Pokémon TCG. Jynx first appeared in the Base Set with her black-skinned design, but later reprints of this card have the purple-skinned design. ==Controversy and reception== [[File:Jynx-blackface.gif|left|thumb|140px|Jynx's original design has been heavily criticized as resembling [[blackface]] actors]] Jynx's appearance and design have received criticisms in various publications. Children's book author and cultural critic [[Carole Boston Weatherford]] published an article in the ''[[News & Record|Greensboro News & Record]]'' alleging that Jynx's design bore a striking resemblance to [[blackface]] actors, an image considered [[racism|racist]] against black people,{{cite journal|title=Politically Incorrect Pokémon, One Of The Pokémon Characters Reinforces An Offensive Racial Stereotype|author=[[Carole Boston Weatherford]]|journal=Greensboro News & Record|location=Greensboro, N.C.|date=2000-01-16|page=H.3}} and further described the Pokémon as "a dead ringer for an obese [[drag queen]]." She further criticized the Pokémon in the magazine ''[[Advertising Age]]'', comparing it to ''[[Little Black Sambo]]'' and suggesting its English name as also a possible derogatory remark towards blacks relating to [[Haitian Vodou|voodoo]] (with its original Japanese name, Rougela, being unrelated).{{cite journal|author=Carole Boston Weatherford|title=Pokemon phenom harbors racist image;Jynx character is a stereotype comparable to Little Black Sambo|journal=[[Advertising Age]]|date=2000-02-28|publisher=Crain Communications, Inc.}} Since then, the Jim Crow Museum at [[Ferris State University]] has listed Jynx as an example of racism in modern material.{{cite web |url=http://www.ferris.edu/jimcrow/newforms/|title=New Racist Forms: Jim Crow in the 21st Century|publisher=The Jim Crow Museum, [[Ferris State University]]|author=David Pilgrim|accessdate=2018-01-04}} In response, Game Freak modified Jynx's design in localized versions of the games, a change which would several years later be reflected in the Japanese versions of the games and the [[Pokémon (anime)|anime series]].{{cite web|url=http://videogames.yahoo.com/events/a-decade-of-pokemon-scandals/a-decade-of-pokemon-scandals/1299469/5|publisher=[[Yahoo]]|title=A Decade of Pokemon Scandals - Jynx Incites Racial Backlash|accessdate=2009-06-09|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090330005518/http://videogames.yahoo.com/events/a-decade-of-pokemon-scandals/a-decade-of-pokemon-scandals/1299469/5|archivedate=2009-03-30|deadurl=yes|df=}} In addition, episodes featuring the older Jynx design were censored or completely removed from televised syndication by [[Warner Bros.]]{{cite web|author=Jack DeVries|website=IGN|publisher=News Corporation|title=Pokemon Report: You Can't Do That on Television|date=2009-02-02|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2009/02/02/pokemon-report-you-cant-do-that-on-television?page=2|accessdate=2018-01-04}} Criticisms still persist, such as [[1UP.com]] which, in an article discussing the "lamest Pokémon" of the series, referred to it as the "infamous blackface Pokémon".{{cite web|author=Kat Bailey|website=[[1UP.com]]|publisher=[[UGO Networks]]|title=Top 5 Lamest Pokemon|url=http://www.1up.com/do/feature?cId=3169539|accessdate=2009-06-09|archivedate=2009-03-25|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090325020940/http://www.1up.com/do/feature?cId=3169539|deadurl=yes|df=}} ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'' writer Mary C. Morton described Jynx as having "explicitly, albeit grossly caricatured, womanly features", and challenged the assertion that the games crossed gender barriers with such.{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|title=Pokemon: The Dark Side|author=Mary C. Morton|date=1999-09-14}} In their [[podcast]], ''[[Retronauts]]'', they emphasized it further, noting the design as "creepy" and that it maintained the issue of racism still.{{cite podcast|url=http://www.1up.com/do/minisite?cId=3156908|title=Retronauts Episode 18|website=[[1UP.com]]|publisher=[[UGO Networks]]|host=Jerry Parish, James Mielke, Ryan O'Donnell, Richard Li, Shane Bettenhausen.|date=2007-04-05|accessdate=2009-06-10|archivedate=2009-02-26|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090226035617/http://www.1up.com/do/minisite?cId=3156908|deadurl=yes|df=}} ''[[IGN]]'' also criticized the design, characterizing Jynx as a "transvestite midget in racially offensive makeup".{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2008/11/14/pokemon-report-do-not-want|title=Pokemon Report: Do Not Want|website=IGN|publisher=News Corporation|first=Jack|last=DeVries|date=2008-11-14|accessdate=2018-01-04}} [[GameDaily]] ranked it first on their list of the "Top 10 Weirdest Looking Pokémon", noting its design suggested the presence of breasts, and echoing qualms regarding its resemblance to blackface performers.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamedaily.com/articles/galleries/top-10-weirdest-looking-pokemon/?page=10|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415052735/http://www.gamedaily.com/articles/galleries/top-10-weirdest-looking-pokemon/?page=10|archivedate=2009-04-15|title=Top 10 Weirdest Looking Pokémon|publisher=[[AOL]]|work=[[GameDaily]]|accessdate=2009-06-09|author=Chris Buffa|deadurl=yes|df=}} [[Games.net]] ranked it fourth on their "Top 10 Disturbingly Sexual Game Characters" list, questioning why the character was clothed in what resembled a "slinky dress and push-up bra".{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080830084600/http://www.games.net/article/netten/2/116901/top-ten-disturbingly-sexual-game-characters/|url=http://www.games.net/article/netten/2/116901/top-ten-disturbingly-sexual-game-characters/|archivedate=2008-08-30|title=Top Ten Disturbingly Sexual Game Characters|author1=Ben Karl|author2=Dave Rudden|date=2007-10-05|accessdate=2007-10-12|publisher=games.net|deadurl=yes|df=}} On the other hand, the book ''Gaming Cultures and Place in Asia-Pacific'' defended Jynx's design, suggesting Sugimori developed it to draw upon the humor of heta-uma (a term meaning bad/nice), and described the design as oscillating between the poles of good and bad, as a result offering diversity within the game and inviting scrutiny from players.{{cite book|title=Gaming Cultures and Place in Asia-Pacific|author1=Larissa Hjorth|author2=David Surman|year=2009|publisher=[[Routledge]]/[[Taylor & Francis]]|isbn=0-415-99627-9|edition=1st|chapter=9|pages=314}} [[GamesRadar]] described [[List of generation I Pokémon#Magmar|Magmar]] and Jynx as the [[Romeo and Juliet]] of Pokémon.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/pokemusings-week-32/2/|title=Pokemusings, week 32, page 2|website=[[GamesRadar+]]|accessdate=2018-01-04}} GamesRadar's Carolyn Gudmundson compared Jynx to the [[Gothita|Gothita line]] due to both's designs being based on an "overtly feminine form", though describing Gothita's line as "way less creepy".{{cite web|author=Carolyn Gudmundson|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/pokemon-black-and-white-pokedex-gothita-gothorita-gothitelle/|title=Pokemon Black and White Pokedex - Gothita, Gothorita, Gothitelle|website=GamesRadar+|date=2011-03-01|accessdate=2018-01-04}} Author Loredana Lipperini described Jynx as an "opera singer".{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MOQc163-XCcC|title=Generazione Pokémon: I bambini e l'invasione planetaria dei nuovi "giocattoli di ruolo"|isbn=9788882102494|author=Loredana Lipperini|year=2000|publisher=Castelvecchi|pages=235}} GamesRadar editor Carolyn Gudmundson listed "Humanoid" as one of the most overused Pokémon designs, listing Jynx and [[Mr. Mime]] as one of "the most infamous" examples.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesradar.com/the-most-overused-pokemon-designs/2/|title=The most overused Pokemon designs, Pokemon HeartGold / SoulSilver DS Features|website=GamesRadar+|author=Carolyn Gudmundson|date=2010-07-24|accessdate=2018-01-04}} ==See also== {{Portal|Pokémon}} *[[Pokémon episodes removed from rotation]], a list of episodes of the Kurenai Densetsu | director = Takaomi Kanasaki | producer = | writer = [[Makoto Uezu]] | music = Masato Kōda | studio = [[J.C.Staff]] | licensee = | released = {{Start date|2019}} | runtime = }} {{Infobox animanga/Footer}} {{nihongo|'''''KonoSuba: God's Blessing on this Wonderful World!'''''|この素晴らしい世界に祝福を！|Kono Subarashii Sekai ni Shukufuku o!|literally "A blessing to this wonderful world!"|lead=yes}} is a Japanese [[light novel]] series written by Natsume Akatsuki. The series follows a boy who is sent to a fantasy world following his death, forming a dysfunctional party with a goddess, a wizard, and a crusader to fight against monsters. Beginning as a [[web novel]] series published on ''[[Shousetsuka ni Narou]]'' between December 2012 and October 2013, the series was revised into a printed [[light novel]] series with illustrations by Kurone Mishima, which began publication under [[Kadokawa Shoten]]'s ''[[Kadokawa Sneaker Bunko]]'' [[Imprint (trade name)|Imprint]] from October 2013. A [[manga]] adaptation, illustrated by Masahito Watari and Joseph Yokobori, began serialization in [[Fujimi Shobo]]'s ''[[Monthly Dragon Age]]'' magazine from October 2014. A radio [[drama CD]] was released by HobiRecords in March 2015, and an [[anime]] television adaptation by [[Studio Deen]] aired in Japan between January and March 2016. A second season of the anime aired between January and March 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-03-16/konosuba-anime-gets-2nd-season/.99855|title=KonoSuba Anime Gets 2nd Season|date=March 16, 2016|website=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=March 16, 2016}}{{cite web |url=http://nagamedigital.com/2016/11/14/konosuba-season-2-release-date/|title=KONOSUBA SEASON 2 GETS OFFICIAL RELEASE DATE, PV AND KEY VISUAL|date=November 14, 2016 |website=nagamedigital.com|accessdate=November 14, 2016 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/daily-briefs/2016-06-24/konosuba-tv-anime-2nd-season-premieres-in-january/.103579 |title=KonoSuba TV Anime's 2nd Season Premieres in January |date=June 24, 2016 |website=[[Anime News Network]] |accessdate=June 24, 2016 }} A spin-off light novel series, ''Kono Subarashii Sekai ni Bakuen o!'', began publication from July 2014. Both the light novels and the manga are licensed in North America by [[Yen Press]]. An anime film adaptation by [[J.C.Staff]] titled ''Kono Subarashii Sekai ni Shukufuku o! Kurenai Densetsu'' will premiere in 2019. ==Plot== {{See also|List of KonoSuba characters}} Following an untimely and embarrassing death, Kazuma Satō, a Japanese teenager [[hikikomori|shut-in]] [[NEET]], meets a goddess named Aqua, who offers to reincarnate him in a [[parallel universe (fiction)|parallel world]] with [[Massively multiplayer online role-playing game|MMORPG]] elements, where he can go on adventures and battle monsters. Despite being offered a superpowered item or ability to use in this new world, Kazuma, following some provocation, chooses Aqua herself to accompany him to the town of Axel, quickly finding her absent-mindedness to be less than beneficial.{{ref|LN|LN 1.P}} With Aqua unable to return to the afterlife until the [[Dark Lord (fiction)|Devil King]] is defeated, the two form a [[Party (role-playing games)|party]] and recruit two other members; an explosion-obsessed magician named Megumin and a masochistic crusader named Darkness.{{ref|LN|LN 1.2.4}} Due to the party's dysfunctional abilities, Kazuma quickly gives up on the idea of defeating the Devil King and tries to live a luxurious lifestyle, only to find the circumstances of his daily life are forcing him and his party to encounter and battle the Devil King's generals.{{ref|LN|LN 2.3}} ==Media== ===Novels=== {{See also|List of KonoSuba volumes#Light novels}} The original [[web novel]] series written by Natsume Akatsuki was published on Syosetu between December 2012 and October 2013.{{cite web| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131127132412/http://ncode.syosetu.com/n7145bl/| archivedate=November 27, 2013| url=http://ncode.syosetu.com/n7145bl/| title=KonoSuba web novel| publisher=Syosetu| language=Japanese| accessdate=February 8, 2016}} The author also wrote a side story featuring [[#Wiz|Wiz]] and Vanir.{{cite web| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130729143507/http://ncode.syosetu.com/n7364bo/| archivedate=July 29, 2013| url=http://ncode.syosetu.com/n7145bl/| title=The Masked Demon's Dream Watching| publisher=Syosetu| language=Japanese| accessdate=February 8, 2016}} Akatsuki, who enjoyed playing fantasy video games like ''[[Wizardry]]'' and ''[[Final Fantasy]]'', also derived much of ''KonoSuba''{{'s}} fantasy elements from [[tabletop role-playing game]]s.{{cite web|last=Green|first=Scott|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2017/04/26-1/the-anime-man-interviews-konosuba-creator|title=The Anime Man Interviews "Konosuba" Creator|publisher=[[Crunchyroll]]|date=April 26, 2017|accessdate=September 1, 2017}} A [[light novel]] version with illustrations by Kurone Mishima began release under [[Kadokawa Shoten]]'s [[Kadokawa Sneaker Bunko]] [[Imprint (trade name)|imprint]] from October 1, 2013,{{cite web| url=http://sneakerbunko.jp/bookdetails/index.php?pcd=321307000151| script-title=ja:この素晴らしい世界に祝福を！| publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]| accessdate=May 30, 2015| language=Japanese}} with thirteen volumes released as of December 1, 2017.{{cite web| url=http://sneakerbunko.jp/bookdetails/index.php?pcd=321706000257| script-title=ja:この素晴らしい世界に祝福を!13| publisher=[[Kadokawa Shoten]]| accessdate=January 20, 2018| language=Japanese}} The light novel diverges significantly from the web novel's plot from the sixth volume onwards,{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} and also features changes to the characters' ages. A Megumin-focused [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] light novel series, also written and illustrated by Akatsuki and Mishima respectively, titled {{nihongo3|lit. Anime Film Opens in 2019|date=October 20, 2018|publisher=Anime News Network|accessdate=October 20, 2018}} ===Other media=== A radio [[drama CD]], featuring a different voice cast to the anime, was released by HobiRecords on March 1, 2015.{{cite web| url=https://www.toranoana.jp/info/dojin/konosuba/| title=KonoSuba Drama CD| publisher=[[Comic Toranoana]]| language=Japanese| accessdate=January 29, 2016}} A second drama CD, along with an original soundtrack by [[Kouda Masato]] and a [[character song]] album, was released in March 2017.{{cite web|url=https://otakumode.com/news/5891ab30e088942e19129b4f/March-Is-KonoSuba-Month-New-Original-Soundtrack-Drama-CD-Character-Song-Album-Slated-for-Release!|title=March Is KonoSuba Month - New Original Soundtrack, Drama CD & Character Song Album Slated for Release!|work=Tokyo Otaku Mode News|date=February 2, 2017|accessdate=August 26, 2017}} ==Reception== The ''KonoSuba'' light novels have been quite popular. As of March 2, 2016, the 11-volume series has a total of 1.5 million copies in print, each volume selling 136,000 copies.{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2016/03/02/konosuba-novel-sales-increases-three-times-thanks-to-tv-anime|title='KonoSuba' Novel Sales Increases Three Times Thanks to TV Anime|publisher=[[Crunchyroll]]|date=March 2, 2016|first=Mikikazu|last=Komatsu}} As of February 2017, the light novels had three million copies in print.{{cite web|last=Green|first=Scott|url=https://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2017/02/03/konosuba-art-book-commercial-explodes-online|title="Konosuba" Art Book Commercial Explodes Online|publisher=[[Crunchyroll]]|date=February 3, 2017|accessdate=August 26, 2017}} In a review of the first novel, Andy Hanley praised the series' comedy reflected in the "tired genre" as well as its cast finding them appealing based on their traits. However, Hanley criticized the short length of the first volume.{{cite web |url=http://www.uk-anime.net/manga/Konosuba:_God's_Blessing_on_This_Wonderful_World!_-_Vol._1_(Light_novel).html |title=MANGA REVIEW: Konosuba: God's Blessing on This Wonderful World! - Vol. 1 (Light novel) |last=Hanley |first=Andy|date=February 28, 2017 |website=UK Anime|accessdate=April 11, 2017}} The series won [[BookWalker]]'s 2016 Grand Prix Award.{{cite web|last=Komatsu|first=Mikizaku|url=https://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2017/02/03/konosuba-gods-blessing-on-this-wonderful-world-wins-book-walker-grand-prix-award-2016|title="KONOSUBA -God's blessing on this wonderful world!" Wins Book Walker Grand Prix Award 2016|publisher=[[Crunchyroll]]|date=February 3, 2017|accessdate=September 1, 2017}} {{quote box|align=right|width=25em|quote=''KonoSuba: God's Blessing on This Wonderful World'' is an anime that has a lot of fun mocking the tropes of the typical JRPG fantasy world via a colorful cast of characters that are enjoyable in their own right. The comedy is so spot-on with its deadpan nature that it's hard not to be drawn in by that alone.|source=– Richard Eisenbeis, in his review of the anime}} Like its light novel counterpart, the anime has received positive reception for its comedy, parody of the "trapped in a fantasy world" subgenre, and faithful adaptation of the light novels. Reviewing the first few episodes, [[Anime News Network]] (ANN)'s Theron Martin described the second episode as "the funniest episode of anime I have seen since ''[[Monthly Girls' Nozaki-kun]]'' aired", while also praising the series' musical score.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/konosuba-god-blessing-on-this-wonderful-world/episodes-1-2/.97800 |title=KonoSuba – God's blessing on this wonderful world!! Episodes 1-2 |last=Martin |first=Theron |date=January 21, 2016 |website=[[Anime News Network]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170802104838/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/konosuba-god-blessing-on-this-wonderful-world/episodes-1-2/.97800|archivedate=August 2, 2017}} The voice acting has also been a subject of praise; Nick Creamer of ANN commended Sora Amamiya and Rie Takahashi's roles as Aqua and Megumin for the energy provided in their performances, while Martin applauded Jun Fukushima for his work in voicing Kazuma, considering his dry tone an additional factor in the show's humor.{{cite web|last=Martin|first=Theron|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/konosuba-god-blessing-on-this-wonderful-world-2/episode-7/.112580|title=KONOSUBA - God's blessing on this wonderful world! 2 - Episode 7|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=February 23, 2017|accessdate=September 1, 2017|quote=Week in and week out, Jun Fukushima knocks it out of the park with his perfectly-measured rendition of Kazuma. In every scene, his inflection and tone is exactly right to milk the maximum value out of a scene's comedy potential. ... The female seiyuu are nailing their roles too, but many scenes in this series wouldn't be half as funny without Kazuma's dry wit as the slightly-less-crazy center of a crazy maelstrom.}} In contrast, a common criticism of the anime was its inconsistent character animation, one that was described as "low budget" as characters appeared [[off-model]].{{cite web|last=Morrissy|first=Kim|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-feature/2017/02/27-1/feature-novel-vs-anime-konosuba|title=FEATURE: Novel vs Anime - "Konosuba"|publisher=[[Crunchyroll]]|date=February 27, 2017|accessdate=August 25, 2017}} Koichi Kikuta responded by stating such design was intentional, hoping to "bring out the individuality of each character" rather than the prettier artwork in the light novels; to do this, Kikuta's animation displayed "their more human sides, like their unflattering traits and their distressed moments."{{cite web|url=https://wavemotioncannon.com/2017/02/07/konosuba-interview-with-koichi-kikuta-anime-style-009-july-2016/|title=Konosuba Interview with Koichi Kikuta (Anime Style 009, July 2016)|work=Wave Motion Cannon|date=February 7, 2017|accessdate=August 25, 2017}} [[Crunchyroll]]'s Kim Morrissy considered the animation to be humorous, especially fitting in a comedic anime. [[Kotaku]] writer Richard Eisenbeis explained much of the series' humor derives from the deconstruction of Kazuma's hopes of becoming the hero of a fantasy world, instead realizing he is forced to struggle his way through the world.{{cite web|last=Eisenbeis|first=Richard|url=https://kotaku.com/when-your-new-life-in-a-jrpg-world-doesn-t-live-up-to-e-1778353269|title=When Your New Life in a JRPG World Doesn't Live Up to Expectations|publisher=[[Kotaku]]|date=May 26, 2016|accessdate=August 25, 2017}} Comparing Kazuma's problems in a fantasy world to those in real life, Creamer wrote about a sense of relatability between the series' protagonists and the audience, as the party deals with issues like debt and taking questionable jobs because of high pay. On a critical note, Creamer disapproved of Kazuma's negative attitude, which he felt harmed the comedy in the series.{{cite web|last=Creamer|first=Nick|url=https://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/konosuba-god-blessing-on-this-wonderful-world-episodes-1-10-streaming/.100209|title=KonoSuba – God's Blessing on This Wonderful World! [Episodes 1-10 Streaming]|publisher=[[Anime News Network]]|date=March 25, 2016|accessdate=August 30, 2017}} ''KonoSuba''{{'s}} characters, especially those in Kazuma's party, have gained favorable thoughts in the anime community. Creamer described the group as possessing a "strange but endearing chemistry," as the members are unfriendly with one another, yet are close. Morrissy added the party's "emotional bond is also evident in the ways they interact with each other. My favorite thing about the anime is that it takes the time to draw these nuances out onscreen and express them with visual flair." Megumin in particular has been considered one of the series' most popular characters, winning Sneaker Bunko's official Favorite ''KonoSuba'' Character poll.{{cite web|url=https://sneakerbunko.jp/special/konosuba-charavote/index.php|title=KonoSuba Character Poll|work=[[Kadokawa Sneaker Bunko]]|accessdate=September 1, 2017|language=Japanese}} She was also the sixth-highest vote in ''[[Newtype]]''{{'s}} 2015–16 Awards for Best Female Character (Kazuma was third in the male category) and received the most "Other" votes in the Best Girl category in [[Crunchyroll]]'s Anime Awards 2016.{{cite web|last=Green|first=Scott|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2016/10/09/japanese-fans-pick-favorite-anime-from-last-twelve-months-in-newtype-awards|title=Japanese Fans Pick Favorite Anime From Last Twelve Months In Newtype Awards|publisher=[[Crunchyroll]]|date=October 9, 2016|accessdate=September 1, 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-feature/2017/01/10-1/feature-crunchyroll-anime-awards-the-results-are-in-see-who-won|title=FEATURE: Crunchyroll Anime Awards - The Results are In! See Who Won!|work=[[Crunchyroll]]|date=January 10, 2017|accessdate=September 1, 2017}} In an interview with internet personality The Anime Man, Natsume Akatsuki described Megumin as giving off "a pure and elegant atmosphere" like one of an anime heroine or [[waifu]], hence her popularity among fans. In 2016, the anime was voted the tenth-best TV anime in the ''Newtype'' 2015–16 Awards. ''KonoSuba'' also finished runner-up for Best Comedy in the Anime Awards 2016 to ''[[Haven't You Heard? I'm Sakamoto]]''. ==Notes== *{{note|LN|LN}} represents the Light Novel of the series in the format of X.Y.Z, where X represents the volume, Y represents the chapter, and Z represents the part. Chapter P represents the [[prologue]] while chapter A represents the [[afterword]] of the novel. Ex. and M. refer to the ''Explosions'' (''Sekai ni Bakuen o!'') and ''Consulting with the Masked Devil'' (''Kono Kamen no Akuma ni Sōdan wo!'') spin-offs. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|KonoSuba}} *{{Official website|https://sneakerbunko.jp/series/konosuba/}} {{ja icon}} *{{Official website|https://konosuba.com/|Official anime website}} {{ja icon}} *{{Official website|https://www.fujimishobo.co.jp/sp/201504konosuba/|Official manga website}} {{ja icon}} *{{ann|light novel|18158}} {{Konosuba}} {{Studio Deen}} {{J.C.Staff}} [[Category:2013 Japanese novels]] [[Category:2014 Japanese novels]] [[Category:2016 anime OVAs]] [[Category:2016 Japanese novels]] [[Category:2017 video games]] [[Category:Anime and manga based on light novels]] [[Category:Comedy anime and manga]] [[Category:Crunchyroll]] [[Category:Fantasy anime and manga]] [[Category:Fujimi Shobo manga]] [[Category:Isekai anime and manga]] [[Category:J.C.Staff]] [[Category:Kadokawa Sneaker Bunko]] [[Category:Kadokawa Dwango franchises]] [[Category:Light novels]] [[Category:Light novels first published online]] [[Category:Media Factory manga]] [[Category:Media franchises]] [[Category:MMORPGs in fiction]] [[Category:Monarchy in fiction]] [[Category:Novels about the afterlife]] [[Category:Reincarnation in fiction]] [[Category:Screenplays by Makoto Uezu]] [[Category:Shōsetsuka ni Narō]] [[Category:Studio Deen]] [[Category:Shōnen manga]] [[Category:Television programs based on light novels]] [[Category:Tokyo MX shows]] [[Category:Upcoming animated films]] [[Category:Visual novels]] [[Category:Yen Press titles]]

'''Kremvax''' was originally a fictitious [[Usenet]] site at the [[Moscow Kremlin|Kremlin]], named like the then large number of Usenet [[VAX]]en with names of the form [[foo]]vax. Kremvax was announced on April 1, 1984 in a posting ostensibly originated there by [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] leader [[Konstantin Chernenko]]. The posting was actually forged by [[Piet Beertema]] of [[Centrum Wiskunde & Informatica|CWI]] (in Amsterdam) as an [[April Fool's Day|April Fool]]'s joke.<ref name="beert1">{{cite web|url=http://www.godfatherof.nl/kremvax.html|title=The kremvax hoax|last=Beertema|first=Piet|publisher=godfatherof.nl|accessdate=2009-04-11}}</ref> Other fictitious sites mentioned in the [[hoax]] were moskvax and kgbvax. The actual origin of the email was mcvax, one of the first European sites on the internet.<ref name="wired1">{{cite news|url=http://archive.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/magazine/16-04/st_best|title=10 Best: April Fools' Gags (the Web Is Closing for Spring Cleaning!)|last=Novak|first=Asami|date=24 March 2008|publisher=Wired|accessdate=2014-07-23}}</ref>
Six years later Usenet was joined by [[DEMOS_(ISP)|demos.su]], the first genuine site based in [[Moscow]]. Some readers needed convincing that the postings from it were not just another prank. [[Vadim Antonov]], the senior programmer at Demos and the major poster from there until mid-1991, was quite aware of all this, and referred to it frequently in his own postings. Antonov later arranged to have the domain's gateway site named kremvax.demos.su, turning fiction into truth and, according to one account, "demonstrating that the hackish sense of humor transcends cultural barriers".<ref>[[Eric S. Raymond|Raymond, E. S.]]: "The [[Jargon File]]", [http://catb.org/~esr/jargon/html/K/kremvax.html Kremvax entry], 2006</ref>
